(Same as AMST 385 2)
Instructor is Visiting Assistant Professor, Dr. Jennifer Morgan.


On the eve of the American Revolution, people who lived in the Atlantic colonies did not necessarily envision themselves as revolutionaries. And not every British colony would become part of the U.S. So how did ideas about liberty and equality take shape in light of the centrality of dispossession and enslavement to the long process of colonization? How were ideas about race and gender important to understanding these developments? 
This semester, we will investigate the formation of revolutionary ideas within a broader Atlantic framework in which key events and colonial economies shaped and were shaped by ideas about race, gender, and social status.
course_description: Examines the intellectual and social context of the American Revolution. Issues covered include the causes and development of revolutionary sentiment, the military conflict, diplomacy, economics, and American constitutional government.
